title: German submarine U-1022
text:
German submarine "U-1022" was a <a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIC.2F41">Type VIIC/41</a> <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> of <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>'s "<a href="Kriegsmarine">Kriegsmarine</a>". She was <a href="Keel%20laying">laid down</a> on 6 May 1943 by <a href="Blohm%20%26amp%3B%20Voss">Blohm & Voss</a> in <a href="Hamburg">Hamburg</a>, Germany, and <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> on 7 June 1944, the day after the <a href="Operation%20Overlord">Allied landings in Normandy</a>, with "<a href="Kapit%C3%A4nleutnant">Kapitänleutnant</a>" Hans-Joachim Ernst in command. She sank two ships for a total of 1,720 metric tonnes. After the war she was handed over to the Allies and sunk in <a href="Operation%20Deadlight">Operation Deadlight</a>.
Construction and design.
<a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIC/41">German Type VIIC/41 submarines</a> were preceded by the heavier <a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIC">Type VIIC submarines</a>. "U-1022" had a displacement of when at the surface and while submerged. She had a total length of , a <a href="pressure%20hull">pressure hull</a> length of , a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of , a height of , and a <a href="draught%20%28ship%29">draught</a> of . The submarine was powered by two <a href="Germaniawerft">Germaniawerft</a> F46 four-stroke, six-cylinder <a href="supercharged">supercharged</a> <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a>s producing a total of for use while surfaced, two <a href="Brown%2C%20Boveri%20%26amp%3B%20Cie">Brown, Boveri & Cie</a> GG UB 720/8 <a href="Motor%E2%80%93generator">double-acting electric motors</a> producing a total of for use while submerged. She had two shafts and two <a href="propeller">propeller</a>s. The boat was capable of operating at depths of up to .
The submarine had a maximum surface speed of and a maximum submerged speed of . When submerged, the boat could operate for at ; when surfaced, she could travel at . "U-1022" was fitted with five <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s (four fitted at the bow and one at the stern), fourteen <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es, one <a href="8.8%20cm%20SK%20C/35%20naval%20gun">SK C/35 naval gun</a>, (220 rounds), one <a href="3.7%20cm%20Flak%2018/36/37/43">Flak M42</a> and two <a href="2%20cm%20FlaK%2030">C/30</a> anti-aircraft guns. The boat had a <a href="Ship%27s%20company">complement</a> of between forty-four and sixty.
Service history.
"U-1022" was ordered by the "Kriegsmarine" on 13 June 1942. She was <a href="Keel%20laying">laid down</a> less than one year later at <a href="Blohm%20%26amp%3B%20Voss">Blohm & Voss</a>, <a href="Hamburg">Hamburg</a> on 6 May 1943 . "U-1022" was <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">launched</a> from Hamburg on 13 April 1944. She was formally commissioned later that year on 7 June 1944, the day after the Allied landings at Normandy. After her training (during which she travelled from Germany to Norway), "U-1022" left her home <a href="port%20of%20Bergen">port of Bergen</a>, Norway on her first and only patrol. During this patrol, which lasted 49 days, "U-1022" traveled from Norway to the southern coast of Iceland. In this time span she managed to sink two enemy vessels, the Panamanian steam merchant "Alcedo" for a loss of 1,392 tonnes and the British vessel, for a loss of 328 tonnes. "U-1022" arrived back in Bergen on 1 April 1945 and remained in port for the remainder of the war. Following Germany's defeat in the war, "U-1022" along with most of the remaining German submarine fleet were sunk in <a href="Operation%20Deadlight">Operation Deadlight</a>.
